payload: Dear John, Jonathan and I met with IBJ today to try and push our negotiations through to the end. They are still unwilling to do a CSA with us but very significantly their back / mid office is currently looking at getting systems support in place which would permit them to do a CSA with us in due course. They acknowledged to us of their own volition that the market trend is towards CSAs even in transactions where the counter party is not a bank. They did say though that it would be a few months before they would be set up to do so. Pls note that they did not agree to do a CSA with us as soon as they are set up to do so but they now know we will come knocking at some stage to ask them to do it so I think we have gone as far as we can on this for now. We will therefore move forward on the credit matrix in the meantime, if you are still willing to do so. The bank has a credit rating of A, so I guess this means US$15 million credit limit. On the assumption that it is possible to draft these terms into a contract without a full CSA, I wonder who is best to do this drafting. I should be able to do the negotiations but I am not sure that I am able to do the drafting .... Alan, do you have any suggestions? Most of the other issues are sorted now but they still want to change the "Threshold Amount" definition to US$10 million. Is there any flexibility on this? Thanks. Jane Mc

payload: Jane: Typically, we have been widely successful in convincing counterpaties (wherever located) to agree to either NY or English law to govern ISDA's because NY and England have well developed bodies of financial law and the courts are more likely to understand derivatives transactions. I also have understood from Terry Taneka at IBJ (and an ISDA director) that Japanese financial institutions regularly agree to NY and English law. I realize here we are talking about a Japanese insurance company counterparty. I think, in this instance, it is ok to agree to Japanese law and courts to get this first Japanese Weather deal documented, but I would like for us to strongly reserve with this company the right to discuss further the choice of law/jurisdiction since I presume we will be negotiating a Master Agreement with them. Also, the submission to jurisdiction clause should be non-exclusive. My previous understanding from Jeremy Pitts of B&M was that ISDA's (and the subject derivative transaction) are enforceable under Japanese law (and that netting is also generally enforceable). I also have understood from B&M that Japanese courts are very preferable to Japanese arbitrations. Please confirm these points with Jeremy before finalizing the document. We will need to finalize our thoughts about the markets we are trying to develop and what the best approach should be to choice of law/jurisdiction going forward. This would be a good topic for Mark E., David, you and I to discuss at our first group meeting. Alan Jane McBride@ENRON 10/17/2000 02:21 AM To: Alan Aronowitz/HOU/

payload: Jane: Typically, we have been widely successful in convincing counterpaties (wherever located) to agree to either NY or English law to govern ISDA's because NY and England have well developed bodies of financial law and the courts are more likely to understand derivatives transactions. I also have understood from Terry Taneka at IBJ (and an ISDA director) that Japanese financial institutions regularly agree to NY and English law. I realize here we are talking about a Japanese insurance company counterparty. I think, in this instance, it is ok to agree to Japanese law and courts to get this first Japanese Weather deal documented, but I would like for us to strongly reserve with this company the right to discuss further the choice of law/jurisdiction since I presume we will be negotiating a Master Agreement with them. Also, the submission to jurisdiction clause should be non-exclusive. My previous understanding from Jeremy Pitts of B&M was that ISDA's (and the subject derivative transaction) are enforceable under Japanese law (and that netting is also generally enforceable). I also have understood from B&M that Japanese courts are very preferable to Japanese arbitrations. Please confirm these points with Jeremy before finalizing the document. We will need to finalize our thoughts about the markets we are trying to develop and what the best approach should be to choice of law/jurisdiction going forward. This would be a good topic for Mark E., David, you and I to discuss at our first group meeting. Alan Jane McBride@ENRON 10/17/2000 02:21 AM To: Alan Aronowitz/HOU/
